articles.headline: Rebuffing Israel, U.S. Allows Censure Over Settlements
articles.snippet: The administration’s decision not to veto the United Nations resolution reflected its accumulated frustration over Israeli settlements.
articles.abstract: The administration’s decision not to veto the United Nations resolution reflected its accumulated frustration over Israeli settlements.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Defying extraordinary pressure from President-elect Donald J. Trump and furious lobbying by Israel, the Obama administration on Friday allowed the United Nations Security Council to adopt a resolution that condemned Israeli settlement construction.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: To Stop Price Spikes on Prescription Drugs, a Widening Radar
articles.snippet: It is unclear where the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging might set its sights next after its report on price gouging by drug makers.
articles.abstract: It is unclear where the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging might set its sights next after its report on price gouging by drug makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional reports can be a snooze. But that is not how I’d characterize Wednesday’s in-depth account of price gouging among prescription drug makers. The 130-page narrative prepared by the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging was juicy, detailing how four pharmaceutical companies have taken advantage of our health care system to enrich themselves and their executives, harming patients and taxpayers.

articles.headline: Cornerstone: The Rise and Fall of a Health Care Experiment
articles.snippet: A company of doctors tried to link their firm’s compensation to quality over quantity. Then they ran into a buzz saw.
articles.abstract: A company of doctors tried to link their firm’s compensation to quality over quantity. Then they ran into a buzz saw.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH POINT, N.C. — Cornerstone Health Care, a large physician group here, made a big bet a few years back: It would get paid based not on how many procedures its doctors performed, but on how effectively they treated their patients.

articles.headline: Flurry of Settlements Over Toxic Mortgages May Save Banks Billions
articles.snippet: In Washington’s rush to make deals before a new, possibly more sympathetic administration, banks may be paying billions less than once proposed.
articles.abstract: In Washington’s rush to make deals before a new, possibly more sympathetic administration, banks may be paying billions less than once proposed.
articles.lead_paragraph: European banks have rushed to cut deals with prosecutors over longstanding claims that they pushed toxic mortgage securities in the years before the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Ukrainian Farmers, Poised for Growth, Stumble After E.U. Deal
articles.snippet: The plight of the agricultural sector has come to encapsulate a wider disenchantment in the country with a trade agreement signed with the European Union.
articles.abstract: The plight of the agricultural sector has come to encapsulate a wider disenchantment in the country with a trade agreement signed with the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: SADKI-STROYEVKA, Ukraine — A cold wind whips through the streets. Vehicles that enter must drive through a foot-deep, moatlike bath of disinfectant, lest their tires track in disease. Computers raise and lower the levels of light to match circadian rhythms.

articles.headline: Obama, Trump and the Turf War That Has Come to Define the Transition
articles.snippet: A Security Council vote on Israeli settlements in the West Bank is just the latest example of diverging opinions between President Obama and President-elect Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: A Security Council vote on Israeli settlements in the West Bank is just the latest example of diverging opinions between President Obama and President-elect Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump and President Obama have been unfailingly polite toward each other since the election. But with Mr. Trump staking out starkly different positions from Mr. Obama on Israel and other sensitive issues, and the president acting aggressively to protect his legacy, the two have become leaders of what amounts to dueling administrations.

articles.headline: Trump’s Push to Cut Jet Costs Hits a Nerve, but His Demands Face Limitations
articles.snippet: The President-elect may be pitting defense contractors against each to force down prices, but military and political realities may intervene.
articles.abstract: The President-elect may be pitting defense contractors against each to force down prices, but military and political realities may intervene.
articles.lead_paragraph: After meeting with Lockheed Martin’s chief executive on Wednesday about lowering the cost of its new F-35 fighter jet, President-elect Donald J. Trump expressed confidence that Pentagon officials standing with him were “good negotiators” and could “get it done beautifully.”

articles.headline: Intent on Unsettling E.U., Russia Taps Foot Soldiers From the Fringe
articles.snippet: Moscow is cultivating an array of far-right extremist groups, spreading disruption and hoping that a few will develop into important and disruptive players.
articles.abstract: Moscow is cultivating an array of far-right extremist groups, spreading disruption and hoping that a few will develop into important and disruptive players.
articles.lead_paragraph: BONY, Hungary — To his neighbors in a village in western Hungary, 76-year-old Istvan Gyorkos was just an old man who mostly kept to himself. Hardly anyone looked askance at his passion for guns and for training youths in paramilitary tactics.

articles.headline: In American Towns, Private Profits From Public Works
articles.snippet: Desperate towns have turned to private equity firms to manage their waterworks. The deals bring much-needed upgrades, but can carry hefty price tags.
articles.abstract: Desperate towns have turned to private equity firms to manage their waterworks. The deals bring much-needed upgrades, but can carry hefty price tags.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYONNE, N.J. — Nicole Adamczyk’s drinking water used to slosh through a snarl of pipes dating from the Coolidge administration — a rusty, rickety symbol of the nation’s failing infrastructure.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory, Ben Protess and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: A Joyful Bustle to Get Ready for Guests: Syrian Refugees
articles.snippet: In Lancaster, Pa., where resettlement work dates back decades, volunteers and staff members from the Church World Service prepared a home for a family of new arrivals.
articles.abstract: In Lancaster, Pa., where resettlement work dates back decades, volunteers and staff members from the Church World Service prepared a home for a family of new arrivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, Pa. — A dull gray house on a hillside has to become a home. Another Syrian family of refugees will be arriving soon, and this empty, echoing old place needs to be readied in welcome.

articles.headline: Secular Hollywood Quietly Courts the Faithful
articles.snippet: Inviting pastors to movie sets, writing bullet points for sermons, proposing Sunday school lesson plans: All are part of the film industry’s outreach to Christian audiences.
articles.abstract: Inviting pastors to movie sets, writing bullet points for sermons, proposing Sunday school lesson plans: All are part of the film industry’s outreach to Christian audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Roderick Dwayne Belin, a senior A.M.E. Church leader, stood before a gathering of more than 1,000 pastors in a drafty Marriott ballroom in Naperville, Ill., this month and extolled the virtues of a Hollywood movie.

articles.headline: U.S. Transition Puts Israeli Focus Back on Palestinians
articles.snippet: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks to move past the Palestinian conflict and improve regional relations, Mr. Trump’s views may bring the issue back to the fore.
articles.abstract: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks to move past the Palestinian conflict and improve regional relations, Mr. Trump’s views may bring the issue back to the fore.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — On the wall of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office is a giant floor-to-ceiling map with Israel at its center. Mr. Netanyahu likes staring at the map. He regales visitors with stories about how Israel has made friends with so many of the countries shown, some nearby, others far away.

articles.headline: Denying Conflict, Trump Family Tries to Resolve Potential Problems
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump has agreed to shut his charity, weighed a plan for an outside monitor to oversee the Trump Organization and ended some international business projects.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump has agreed to shut his charity, weighed a plan for an outside monitor to oversee the Trump Organization and ended some international business projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Realizing that his presidency could face potentially crippling questions over conflicts of interest, Donald J. Trump and his family are rushing to resolve potential controversies — like shuttering foundations and terminating development deals — even as the president-elect publicly maintains that no legal conflicts exist.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Inside the Trump Organization, the Company That Has Run Trump’s Big World
articles.snippet: An examination of the company reveals a distinctly family business fortified with longtime loyalists that operates less on standardized procedures and more on a culture of Trump.
articles.abstract: An examination of the company reveals a distinctly family business fortified with longtime loyalists that operates less on standardized procedures and more on a culture of Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tiah Joo Kim arrived at the Manhattan headquarters of the Trump Organization to pitch a hotel and condominium project in Vancouver, British Columbia, he expected the famous company with ventures across the globe to come with capacious offices and a staff of hundreds. Instead, he was led through a mere two floors with what appeared to be no more than a few dozen employees. “Lean,” Mr. Tiah, a young Malaysian developer, remembers thinking as he walked the halls.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey, Russ Buettner and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Kidney Fund Seen Insisting on Donations, Contrary to Government Deal
articles.snippet: The charity that helps people get lifesaving dialysis has a special arrangement that has helped it grow large, but it may not be holding up its end of the deal.
articles.abstract: The charity that helps people get lifesaving dialysis has a special arrangement that has helped it grow large, but it may not be holding up its end of the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American Kidney Fund is one of the largest charities in the country, with an annual budget of over $250 million. Its marquee program helps pay insurance premiums for thousands of people who need dialysis, a lifesaving and expensive treatment for kidney failure.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: No Food, No Medicine, No Respite: A Starving Boy’s Death in Venezuela
articles.snippet: The story of a teenager who had gone searching for wild roots to eat but poisoned himself instead seemed to embody everything that had gone wrong amid a national economic crisis.
articles.abstract: The story of a teenager who had gone searching for wild roots to eat but poisoned himself instead seemed to embody everything that had gone wrong amid a national economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATURÍN, Venezuela — His name was Kevin Lara Lugo, and he died on his 16th birthday.

articles.headline: Aboard a U.S. Eye in the Sky, Staring Down ISIS in Iraq and Syria
articles.snippet: Surveillance planes continually gathering data are providing details about the day-to-day actions of the Islamic State and helping guide attacks.
articles.abstract: Surveillance planes continually gathering data are providing details about the day-to-day actions of the Islamic State and helping guide attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABOARD A JOINT STARS SURVEILLANCE PLANE, Over Northern Iraq — Flying at 30,000 feet, the powerful radar aboard this Air Force jet peered deep into Syrian territory, hunting for targets on the ground to strike in the looming offensive to seize Raqqa, the Islamic State’s capital.

articles.headline: Changes Coming to White House Press Room: Who, Where, When and How
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump has shown few reservations about ignoring the norms of presidential media coverage. Journalists are wary of what that might mean.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump has shown few reservations about ignoring the norms of presidential media coverage. Journalists are wary of what that might mean.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the naming of Sean Spicer as White House press secretary, Donald J. Trump has selected a Republican Party insider and communications veteran.

articles.headline: Lessons From 2016 for the News Media, as the Ground Shifts
articles.snippet: A presidential race that made fools of pundits and prognosticators suggests reporters should hew closely to hard facts and leave received wisdom on ice.
articles.abstract: A presidential race that made fools of pundits and prognosticators suggests reporters should hew closely to hard facts and leave received wisdom on ice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting a weekly column about the nexus between media, technology, culture and politics in the middle of the 2016 presidential campaign was like parachuting into a hail of machine-gun crossfire.

articles.headline: For Fact-Checking Website Snopes, a Bigger Role Brings More Attacks
articles.snippet: Internet wrath turned against Snopes after it joined a coalition of websites that will work with Facebook to identify and flag suspicious content.
articles.abstract: Internet wrath turned against Snopes after it joined a coalition of websites that will work with Facebook to identify and flag suspicious content.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The last line of defense against the torrent of half-truths, untruths and outright fakery that make up so much of the modern internet is in a downscale strip mall near the beach.

articles.headline: Brands Start Planning for Unexpected Criticism by Trump
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump is not shy about criticizing companies that draw his ire. Now, marketing experts say, brands must be ready if it happens to them.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump is not shy about criticizing companies that draw his ire. Now, marketing experts say, brands must be ready if it happens to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: H&R Block’s new advertising campaign is one of the more ambitious in the company’s 62-year history. It hired the actor Jon Hamm for his first on-camera spokesman role, a significant coup. And the company ditched its “Refund Season” slogan in favor of a more aggressive pitch: “Get your taxes won.”

articles.headline: ‘Suplex’ in Chinese? Professional Wrestling Tries a Big New Market
articles.snippet: World Wrestling Entertainment tries to bring body slams and drop-kicks to a country where other companies have run into government restrictions.
articles.abstract: World Wrestling Entertainment tries to bring body slams and drop-kicks to a country where other companies have run into government restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Wang Bin looked down. A man wearing a blue skintight unitard writhed at his feet. Mr. Wang grinned. This was the moment he had been waiting for.
